channel.title: Server's or Regular Retail Computers?
channel.description:
Well, I've been looking at new computers for awhile now, and I just recently started looking at used servers. I understand that if I buy one, that I need to install BIOS (I heard the free versions are shitty. I don't know), and then install Windows, or Linux. Along with getting a monitor, other accessories. Anyways, these servers seem like that there better than a retail PC, specification wise. What is the major difference that makes them so cheap?
I was looking at one that was HP DL580 G3/ 4x Intel Xeon 3.00GHz Dual Core/16GB RAM/3x18GB HDD RAID 5 (54 Gb) Which would retail if I'm not wrong ~1200$? So, yeah my main question is what is the difference? How well would they work for a home computer? I don't plan on using it to rent out, or anything.
If this doesn't make sense, ask I'll try to explain more.

item.title: Server's or Regular Retail Computers?
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

The only game I’d probably play would be RuneScape which would be rarely, and I thought I needed BIOS in order to install Windows?

Why don’t I? I must have read wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: Server's or Regular Retail Computers?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:1, topic:446716”]Well, I’ve been looking at new computers for awhile now, and I just recently started looking at used servers. I understand that if I buy one, that I need to install BIOS (I heard the free versions are shitty. I don’t know), and then install Windows, or Linux. Along with getting a monitor, other accessories. Anyways, these servers seem like that there better than a retail PC, specification wise. What is the major difference that makes them so cheap?

I was looking at one that was HP DL580 G3/ 4x Intel Xeon 3.00GHz Dual Core/16GB RAM/3x18GB HDD RAID 5 (54 Gb) Which would retail if I’m not wrong ~1200$? So, yeah my main question is what is the difference? How well would they work for a home computer? I don’t plan on using it to rent out, or anything.

If this doesn’t make sense, ask I’ll try to explain more.[/quote]
install a bios? wtf… usually the only difference is more power (usage and output) and bigger space needed.

AtomicInt_:

Well, the server does have a built-in graphics module, right? I have 16GB RAM, couldn’t I dedicate ~4GB of my RAM for vRAM?

it’s still going to be crap ass slow for gaming

Read full topic

item.title: Server's or Regular Retail Computers?
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

Just build your own computer, get an i7 core processor, 6-8 gbs of ram is all you will need, i doubt you will be running probrams that will take 5-7 gbs or your ram anyways, then just buy an ssd and teh set up raid with a couple other hard drives for massive space or even set up your own nas. You should be able to run programs that dont need high graphics with little problem.

Read full topic

item.title: Server's or Regular Retail Computers?
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

Yeah, I got the gist of how they are used. (Power supplies, low resources, security, etc.)

Would I be better off spending more money on a regular desktop?

Read full topic

item.title: Server's or Regular Retail Computers?
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

AtomicInt_:

I do not need one. As, I don’t do anything that would require a GPU. But, then again, I don’t do anything that would require 16GB RAM or 4x 3.00 GHz processor.

Usually they have lower resource speeds, but higher availability. As in your example, it has 16 GB of RAM. But that 16GB might be running at 800MHz, whereas most commercial RAM is running at 1066-1800 MHz. The same goes for the processor. It probably has more cores, but only running at 3.0 GHz. (which is still pretty good). Another thing is that the mounting and power supplies are different.

Read full topic

item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

I think you would lack a GPU, as such things should be useless on a server.
